awd_titl_txt: Conference: NSF EPSCoR Workshop: Intelligent Manufacturing for Extreme Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
This conference proposes to host a two-day conference at the Center for Advanced Energy Studies (CAES) in Idaho Falls, Idaho. This conference will feature keynotes, panels, and breakout sessions with an estimated sixty participants covering various aspects of intelligent manufacturing for extreme environments. The conference will convene world-class experts, researchers, educators, and students to identify gaps and envision solutions in relevant areas of great importance. The conference will promote exchange of ideas and knowledge during the proposed event and will catalyze new collaborations and research directions that will support the growth of carbon-free advanced nuclear energy research in Idaho, Wyoming, as well as other western states. The conference organizers will use funding for travel grants, recruiting women and persons from underrepresented groups to participate to achieve participation from a diverse section of the society. The outcomes of the conference will include an opportunity for researchers and educators to network and form collaborations and preparation of a full report to inform policy makers, industry, and the academic community of various challenges and opportunities of advanced manufacturing, specifically in the nuclear energy sector.

The overarching goal of this conference proposal is to host a two-day conference on Intelligent Manufacturing for Extreme Environments. The conference will identify gaps and envision solutions for five inter-related challenges of intelligent manufacturing in extreme environments. These challenges are: (1) printable electronics that can survive extreme environments, (2) in situ manufacturing process monitoring and feedback control, (3) machine learning to optimize process variables in manufacturing and materials composition, (4) extreme temperature qualification and testing, and (5) workforce development and community college engagement. Nuclear reactors need to operate under extreme service conditions such as high temperatures, corrosive environment, and high radiation doses. Hence, reactor components must be able to withstand those conditions. Successful innovation would revolutionize the nuclear power sector, enable fast commercial development, create economic opportunities in the US, reduce carbon footprint and associated climate risks, and promote a skilled and highly competitive workforce. The novelty of the conference is the convergent integration of computational design, process control, materials discovery, materials characterization, and workforce development. The conference will provide an opportunity for the community to discuss new scientific research, the needs for future research, gaps in the scientific literature, and provide a conference of national interest that could drive scientific engagement with the broader community including involving researchers from the underrepresented groups, and industry collaborations. The conference will provide opportunities to engage with industry, provide opportunities for community college educators to learn about what is happening at the cutting-edge of manufacturing science, and increase public awareness through science engagement.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project Title: Conference: NSF EPSCoR Workshop: Intelligent Manufacturing for Extreme Environments
Awardee: Regents of the University of Idaho
Award Number: 2328585 

 

The Intelligent Manufacturing for Extreme Environments workshop was held in Idaho Falls, ID at the Center for Advanced Energy Studies (CAES) building on 2-3 May 2023 in support of the National Science Foundation (NSF) Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research: Workshop Opportunities (EPS-WO) program. Nuclear reactors need to operate under extreme service conditions such as high temperatures, corrosive environment, and high radiation doses. Hence, reactor components must be able to withstand those conditions. We envision a future where on-demand manufacture of components for advanced reactor designs is possible. In this future, regulatory bodies accept validated manufacturing processes and standardized feedstocks, thus eliminating the need for testing of individual components. The necessary technologies and regulatory policies do not exist today. Successful innovation would revolutionize the nuclear power sector, enable fast commercial development, create economic opportunities in the US, reduce carbon footprint and associated climate risks, and promote a skilled and highly competitive workforce.

 

The objective of the workshop was to convene world-class experts, researchers, educators, and students to identify gaps and envision solutions for five interrelated challenges for intelligent manufacturing in extreme environments. These challenges included:

 

1) Printable electronics that can survive extreme environments,

2) In-situ manufacturing process monitoring and feedback control,

3) Machine learning to optimize process variables in manufacturing and materials composition,

4) Extreme temperature qualification and testing, and

5) Workforce development and community college engagement.

 

The workshop featured the following major activities: 

 

1) Keynotes from distinguished speakers,

2) Three breakout sessions for discussion from workshop participants in the areas of characterization, processing, and modeling,

3) Invited talks from academia, government, and industry,

4) Coffee breaks, catered lunch for networking,

5) A poster session for students to present their research and a catered dinner,

6) Remarks from Dr. Philip Reppert, Director of Center for Advanced Energy Studies, Idaho National Laboratory, and

7) A group conference report writing session.

 

Following the workshop, notes and comments were collected from participants.

 

The intellectual merit of the conference was the convergent integration of computational design, process control, materials discovery, materials characterization, and workforce development. The conference drew expertise from multiple fields to discuss use-inspired basic research problems of strong interest from the community. This event provided a venue for researchers to share their research results, to foster new collaborations, and to develop a conference report highlighting the intellectual challenges and opportunities to the research community and policy makers. A technical report for the outcomes of the workshop is in preparation that will be submitted through Idaho National Laboratory. It will be published as a publicly available document on the U.S. Department of Energy Office of Scientific and Technical Information (OSTI) website. The report will document the scientific progress reported at the workshop and inform the public about research advances, potential opportunities, and the need for continued investment.

 

The broader impacts of the conference were to foment new collaborations and discuss new directions in the area of advanced manufacturing for extreme environments. Junior and senior faculty had an opportunity to provide oral presentations during the workshop to advance their careers. In addition, workshop participants had opportunities to network and engage with senior scientists and researchers from Idaho National Laboratory and industry. Students presented posters at the poster session and had the opportunity to network with researchers from academia, national laboratories, and industry. The American Nuclear Society (ANS) student chapters for University of Idaho and University of Wyoming were invited and contributed presentations for the poster session. The workshop also included a session on workforce development with participation from the Shoshone-Bannock Tribes, Wyoming Business Council, and College of Eastern Idaho, a community college. Participants highlighted community needs for additional workforce training opportunities and high demand from industry for a skilled workforce.  


Last Modified: 10/30/2024
Modified by: John Russell
